result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (5th or 6th) [Modifiers: Alcohol Fine Enhancer] and Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) [Modifiers: Alcohol Fine Enhancer]. The defendant was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th) [Modifiers: Alcohol Fine Enhancer] and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) [Modifiers: Alcohol Fine Enhancer] was dismissed by the court.

  • John P Rupert was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th) [Modifiers: Alcohol Fine Enhancer], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
On Count #1, the Court sentences Mr. Rupert to  5 years, with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of 2  years, and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 3 years.  This sentence is consecutive to any sentence which the Defendant is presently subject to and serving.  

The Court finds that Mr. Rupert is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program "Boot Camp".
The Court finds that Mr. Rupert is not eligible for the Substance Abuse Program.

records.addlTxt:
[MK] case called at 1:50pm. 
Defendant John P Rupert in court, in custody, with Attorney David Westrick.  DA Susan Happ appears for the State of Wisconsin.
Constitutional rights reviewed; maximum penalties recited; plea of " No Contest " entered on Count #1; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified; the Court accepts the plea, finds Mr. Rupert guilty of Count #1, and orders Judgment of Conviction entered.

On Motion of the State, the Court reads in and dismisses Count #2.

On Count #1, the Court sentences Mr. Rupert to  5 years, with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of 2  years, and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 3 years.  This sentence is consecutive to any sentence which the Defendant is presently subject to and serving.  
The Court finds that Mr. Rupert is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program "Boot Camp".
The Court finds that Mr. Rupert is not eligible for the Substance Abuse Program.
The Court gives  0 days credit for time already served.

The Court orders as conditions of Extended Supervision:
--to undergo AODA assessment and follow through with treatment recommendations per the requirements of the Agent
--to maintain absolute sobriety
--no presence in bars, taverns, liquor stores
--no operation of a motor vehicle without a valid drivers license and the permission of the Agent 
--to comply with DNA sample provision unless it is confirmed that a DNA sample has already been supplied 
--to pay a fine of $6,000 plus costs, surcharges and fees

The Court orders outright [not as conditions of Extended Supervision]: 
--Revocation of drivers license for 36 months
--AODA assessment 
--Jefferson County Victim impact panel attendance
--Ignition Interlock Device required on any vehicle driven by the Defendant for a 36 month period  

Explanation of Determinate Sentence form given to the Defendant
Felony voting prohibition form given to the Defendant.
recess 2:34pm.

Case called at 1:16pm [mo]
Commissioner Fremgen presiding for Intake
Defendant John P Rupert appears via videoconferencing from the Jefferson County Jail, in custody, with Attorney Jeffrey De La Rosa (PD will appoint counsel).  Public Service Special Prosecutor, Melanie Flint appears for the State of Wisconsin.  

On agreement of counsel, the Court finds that the videoconferencing system is sight and sound sufficient. 

Atty. De La Rosa indicates that Mr. Rupert is eligible for Public Defender representation.

Service of Complaint admitted, reading waived, the charge and maximum penalties are recited. 
Preliminary Hearing time limits are waived by both parties.

The Court requires a $5,000  signature bond, with conditions:
 - Not to ingest or use any intoxicants 
-  No presence in bars, taverns, liquor stores or any other place in which the primary function is the service/selling of alcohol
-  No operation of a motor vehicle without a valid drivers license.
-  The Defendant is to report and comply with SCRAM alcohol monitoring program as administered by Wisconsin Community Services.  The Court orders the defendant to SCRAM monitoring through WCS, with the consideration of Remote Breath as an alternative only when WCS verifies that a defendant's work environment or health condition prohibits the SCRAM bracelet.

The Defendant is to comply with all SCRAM Program conditions of participation including payment of program costs and fees.  The Defendant is to report for SCRAM installation in Room 230 of the Jefferson County Courthouse on May 14, 2015 at 1:30pm
recess 1:25  pm. 


NEXT: (1) Pretrial Conference on June 3, 2015 at 9:20am   (2) Status Conference on June 29, 2015 at 1:00pm
